FAMST 46.title: Introduction to Cinema
FAMST 46.comments: Concurrent enrollment in Film and Media Studies 46MS is highly recommended for Film and Media Studies Majors.
FAMST 46.description: An introduction to the study of film as an aesthetic and social phenomenon, and to various methods of critical analysis.

FAMST 46H.title: Introduction to Cinema - Honors
FAMST 46H.prereq_description: Must be taken concurrently with Film and Media Studies 46.
FAMST 46H.comments: Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
FAMST 46H.description: Students receive one unit credit for the honors seminar. Intended for highly motivated Letters and Science Honors students.

FAMST 46MS.title: Major Seminar
FAMST 46MS.prereq_description: Concurrent enrollment in Film and Media Studies 46.
FAMST 46MS.description: Designed for Film and Media Studies majors and students contemplating a major or concentration in film. An intensive introduction to the study of film and to various methods of critical analysis.

FAMST 54.title: Hollywood: Anatomy of an Industry
FAMST 54.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units.
FAMST 54.description: In-depth analysis of the changing world of the motion picture and television industries through dialogues with distinguished Hollywood guests. A range of areas such as directing, producing, screenwriting, acting, etc. are covered.

FAMST 55AAZZ.title: Media Arts: The High and the Low
FAMST 55AAZZ.comments: Open to non-majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units provided letter designations are different.
FAMST 55AAZZ.description: Expands the study of the arts beyond classical paradigms and canons, to include media and communication technologies, industries, and aesthetics  in the domains of radio, film, television, music, and digital media. Versions of the course will explore to what extent contemporary media arts uphold or challenge the boundaries between culture and industry, art and commerce, avant garde and mass cultures, or high and low tastes.

FAMST 55BE.title: Media Arts: The High and the Low: The Beatles

FAMST 55CY.title: Media Arts: The High and the Low: From Robots to Cyborgs

FAMST 55QM.title: Media Arts: The High and the Low: Queen

FAMST 56AAZZ.title: Media Cultures and Thought
FAMST 56AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units provided letter designations are different.
FAMST 56AAZZ.description: Versions of this course will explore social concerns that emerge, or take on a new urgency, within media cultures. Topics may include: audiences and media publics; documentary evidence; risk cultures; pandemic media; cinema and the apocalyptic imagination; online privacy; obscenity; interactivity; piracy; queer and camp; right to information; cultures of dissidence; exploitation media.

FAMST 56MR.title: Media Cultures and Thought: Media Risk

FAMST 56ZM.title: Media Cultures and Thought: GenZ Media

FAMST 70.title: Media Criticism
FAMST 70.description: Develop the analytical tools required for a critical understanding of the interrelationship between media, culture, and society in America. Special attention given to how social structures shape media and how media products in return affect our cultural practices and patterns.

FAMST 70H.title: Media Criticism - Honors
FAMST 70H.prereq_description: Must be taken concurrently with Film and Media Studies 70
FAMST 70H.description: Students receive one unit for the honors seminar. Intended for highly motivated Letters and Science honors students.

FAMST 95.title: Internship in Film/Television
FAMST 95.prereq_description: Film and Media Studies majors only.
FAMST 95.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 4 units.
FAMST 95.description: An opportunity for training, career sampling, and contacts in the film or television industry. Required are approximately 100 hours of work per quarter, a final five-page report, and a supervisor's letter of verification.

FAMST 96.title: Advanced Film Analysis
FAMST 96.prereq_description: Film and Media Studies 46 and 70 with a minimum grade of C.
FAMST 96.description: A study of the basic formal dimensions of cinema: narration, causality, space, time, and sound.

FAMST 99. Independent Studies.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 cumulative GPA. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
FAMST 99. Independent Studies.description: Selected research under the direction of a faculty member.

FAMST 101A.title: History of Cinema: The Silent Film
FAMST 101A.prereq_description: Film and Media Studies 46 and 70 with a minimum grade of C; open to Film and
FAMST 101A.description: International film history from the camera obscura to the close of the silent era in the late 1920's. Historical accounts of film as an aesthetic form, a social force, an economic institution, and a technology are considered.

FAMST 101AH.title: History of Cinema: The Silent Film - Honors
FAMST 101AH.prereq_description: Student must be concurrently enrolled in Film and Media Studies 101A
FAMST 101AH.description: Students receive one unit for the honors seminar. Intended for highly motivated Letters and Science Honors Students.

FAMST 101B.title: History of Cinema: The Development of Sound Film
FAMST 101B.prereq_description: Film and Media Studies 46 and 70 with a minimum grade of C; open to Film and Media Studies majors only.
FAMST 101B.description: International film history from the advent of talkies through the late 1950s. Historical accounts of film as an aesthetic form, a social force, an economic institution, and a technology is considered.

FAMST 101BH.title: History of Cinema: The Development of Sound - Honors
FAMST 101BH.prereq_description: Student must be concurrently enrolled in Film and Media Studies 101B
FAMST 101BH.description: Students receive one unit for the honors seminar. Intended for highly motivated Letters and Science Honors Students.

FAMST 101C.title: History of Cinema: New Waves and Beyond
FAMST 101C.prereq_description: Film and Media Studies 46 and 70 with a minimum grade of C; open to Film and Media Studies majors only.
FAMST 101C.description: International film history since 1959. Historical accounts of film as an aesthetic form, a social force, an economic institution, and a technology is considered.

FAMST 101CH.title: History of Cinema:  New Waves and Beyond
FAMST 101CH.prereq_description: Student must be concurrently enrolled in Film and Media Studies 101C
FAMST 101CH.description: Students receive one unit for the honors seminar. Intended for highly motivated Letters and Science Honors Students.

FAMST 101D.title: History of Electronic Media: Telegraphy to Early Television
FAMST 101D.prereq_description: Film and Media Studies 46 and 70 with a grade of C or better.
FAMST 101D.description: International history of electronic media and broadcasting from telegraphy to early television. Historical accounts of telegraphy, radio, and early television as cultural forms, communications technologies, and social political and economic institutions are considered.

FAMST 101E.title: History of Electronic Media: Network TV to the Digital Era
FAMST 101E.prereq_description: Film and Media Studies 46 and 70 with a minimum grade of C or better.
FAMST 101E.description: International history of electronic media from the 1960s through the present day. Historical accounts of broadcasting, cable, satellites and digital media as cultural forms, communications technologies and social, political and economic institutions are considered.

FAMST 101F.title: Film History: International Cinema from 1989-Present
FAMST 101F.prereq_description: FAMST 96 with a grade of C or better.
FAMST 101F.description: International film history since 1989. Focuses on the expansion of independent and corporate-backed filmmaking around the world after the end of the Cold War as well as on a wide range of industrial, technological, cultural, and aesthetic changes.

FAMST 102.title: Acting and Directing Workshop
FAMST 102.prereq_description: Film and Media Studies 46; and consent of instructor; upper-division film and
FAMST 102.description: Designed as an introduction to the fundamentals and interaction of acting and directing in the creative process of producing a film or video. Every student will write, perform in, direct, and record on video a short work.

FAMST 103.title: Project Development
FAMST 103.prereq_description: Film and Media Studies 46; and, Film and Media Studies 104, or 106A-B; and
FAMST 103.description: A workshop approach to the development of a short film project. Course covers writing, budget preparation, and preproduction, with particular attention to final distribution needs.

FAMST 104.title: Introduction to Production Technology
FAMST 104.prereq_description: Film and Media Studies 46; open to film and media majors only.
FAMST 104.description: An introduction to video production and technology, focusing on the fundamental concepts of the "moving image" including core aspects of shooting, lighting, sound-recording & editing. Lectures complement the hands-on labs by covering key concepts, dissecting various productions, and learning the workflow from pre to post-production.

FAMST 105.title: Historic Production
FAMST 105.prereq_description: Film and Media Studies 46; open to film studies majors only.
FAMST 105.description: Teaches film history as a production workshop. Students will be introduced to the primary technologies and working methods used during three distinct eras in the development of the motion picture. The class will write and produce scenes on 16mm film reflecting the styles and techniques of the silent era.

FAMST 106A.title: Crew Production Part One
FAMST 106A.prereq_description: Film Studies 46; and, 102 or 104 or 107; and consent of instructor.
FAMST 106A.description: Instruction in the basic techniques of filmmaking via the production of crew projects over two consecutive quarters. Pre-production through principal photography.

FAMST 106B.title: Crew Production part two
FAMST 106B.prereq_description: Film Studies 46; and, 102 or 104 or 107; and consent of instructor.
FAMST 106B.description: Instruction in the basic techniques of filmmaking via the production of crew projects over two consecutive quarters. Post-production through exhibition.

FAMST 107.title: Introduction to Animation
FAMST 107.prereq_description: Film and Media Studies 46; open to film and media majors only.
FAMST 107.description: A look at the techniques and history of animation with emphasis on the major styles and methods of production, including cel, direct, photo, three-dimensional and computer. Close examination of significant films combined with production of a class project.

FAMST 107S.title: Contemporary Animation
FAMST 107S.description: Covers the basics of both classical and computer animation from a practical and theoretical point of view. Field trips are taken.

FAMST 108.title: Short Project Production
FAMST 108.prereq_description: Film and Media Studies 46 or consent of instructor.
FAMST 108.description: A workshop approach to the production of individual, short projects. Each student produces a project by the end of the quarter. Admission to this course is determined by creative portfolio.

FAMST 109AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Film Production
FAMST 109AAZZ.prereq_description: Film Studies 46; and, consent of instructor.
FAMST 109AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit provided letter designations are different.
FAMST 109AAZZ.description: Focus on one or more aspects of film production such as music, writing, directing, design, acting, independent filmmaking, cinematography, producing. Topics will vary.

FAMST 110.title: Professional Development
FAMST 110.description: Provides an overview of the career paths available to Film and Media Studies students as well as a practical understanding of how various industries operate. Also matches students with careers that meet their intellectual and professional goals.

FAMST 112.title: Lighting for the Moving Image
FAMST 112.prereq_description: Film and Media Studies 46 or consent of instructor.
FAMST 112.description: A workshop/seminar approach to explorations in how lighting affects the moving image, from theater to film to the computer.

FAMST 113AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Film and Media Studies
FAMST 113AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units, but only 8 units count toward major.
FAMST 113AAZZ.description: Topics in a special area of interest to film and media studies.

FAMST 115.title: Sound Production
FAMST 115.prereq_description: Film Studies 104 or 105; consent of instructor.
FAMST 115.description: A workshop approach to explorations of sound recording, editing, and mixing in project production.

FAMST 115S.title: Advanced Sound Production
FAMST 115S.prereq_description: Film and Media Studies 115, consent of instructor.
FAMST 115S.description: This advanced course takes a workshop approach to explorations and methods of sound post-production, focusing on audio editing, audio repair, mixing and delivery.  Lectures complement the hands-on labs by covering theoretical concepts, examination of significant films, and learning key techniques in sound production.

FAMST 116.title: Editing
FAMST 116.prereq_description: Film Studies 104 and 105; consent of the instructor.
FAMST 116.description: A workshop exploration of the methodologies for post-  production.

FAMST 118.title: Sponsored Campus Production
FAMST 118.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units.
FAMST 118.description: An interface with campus "clients" who provide the budget and goals for crew projects.

FAMST 118GS.title: Green Screen
FAMST 118GS.description: A hands-on, project-based environmental media production course. Students work in teams to leverage their collective production skills and environmental knowledge to create short films, which premiere in the Pollock Theater at the end of the quarter.

FAMST 118LP.title: Launch Pad
FAMST 118LP.description: Launch Pad is an interdepartmental collaboration with the Department of Theater & Dance. Senior BFA acting students work together with Film & Media Studies production teams to create actor reels, short Series and behind-the-scenes documentaries.

FAMST 119.title: Film Festivals
FAMST 119.description: Course to be held during a film festival, students attend screenings, lectures, and Q&A sessions. Writing assignments include: reviews, journals, and expository prose. Preparatory and debriefing meetings and discussion sessions are also part of the course requirements.

FAMST 119ML.title: Film Programming: Magic Lantern
FAMST 119ML.prereq_description: Film and Media Studies 46, or junior status or consent of instructor.
FAMST 119ML.description: Students learn the ins and outs of organizing and executing a film series, using the IV Theater as a lab. They gain hands-on experience programming, contacting and working with distributors and filmmakers, fundraising, advertising, engaging in audience outreach, theater managing, exhibiting, researching, and reviewing.

FAMST 120.title: Japanese Cinema
FAMST 120.description: An introductory scrutiny of major Japanese directors: Mizoguchi, Ozu, Oshima, and Kurosawa. Close attention to their film compositition, choices of subject and character, their ideas of the cinematic, and the relationship of cinema to Japanese culture and society.

FAMST 121.title: Chinese Cinema
FAMST 121.description: An introduction to major Chinese directors from the People's Republic of China, the Republic of China (Taiwan), and Hong Kong. Film composition, choices of subject and character, ideas of the cinematic, and relationship of cinema to Chinese culture and society.

FAMST 122AAZZ.title: Topics in National and Transnational Media
FAMST 122AAZZ.prereq_description: Film and Media Studies 46 or upper-division standing.
FAMST 122AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit, provided the letter designations are different, but only 12 units may be applied toward the major.
FAMST 122AAZZ.description: This course examines film, television, and/or other audio-visual media history in specific national and transnational contexts. Course topics may include: the concepts of nation and national traditions; major periods, genres, themes, and styles; media institutions, state policies, and global infrastructures; and the cultural and political contexts within which audio-visual works are produced and circulate.

FAMST 123.title: Middle East Media
FAMST 123.description: Examines networks of contemporary media from the Middle East with a focus on twenty-first century digital media. Students study the global effect that revealed an architecture of media that were not visible before.

FAMST 124.title: Indian Cinema
FAMST 124.description: Examines the idea of national culture and the cinema of India in terms of major periods, themes, formal parameters, and institutions in relation to both national and international cultural histories.

FAMST 124V.title: Modern Indian Visual Culture
FAMST 124V.description: Introduction of twentieth-century visual culture in India, including painting, architecture, film, television, and graphic arts. Focuses on the themes of nationalism, modernity, and globalization, and the role of the "popular" in Indian visual culture.

FAMST 125AAZZ.title: Topics in Documentary Film and Media Studies
FAMST 125AAZZ.description: With its presumed truth-telling capacity and complex ways of mediating social space, documentary has a deep history as a filmmaking practice, critical studies area, and sociocultural force. Topics in this series study varying perspectives and documentary modes from cinema, television, and video to web-based and multi-modal platforms.

FAMST 125B.title: Documentary Film
FAMST 125B.description: The history of documentary film, as an aesthetic form and social force, from World War II to the present.

FAMST 126.title: Cuban Cinema
FAMST 126.description: Examines the cinema of Cuba in terms of major periods, themes, and formal practices in relation to both national and international cultural histories.

FAMST 127.title: Latin American Cinema
FAMST 127.description: Study of the central issues in the history of Latin American cinema from early developments to the present with an emphasis on the role of nationalism, political and intellectual cultures, aesthetics movements and television in its development.

FAMST 127M.title: Mexican Film and Television
FAMST 127M.description: Explores the historical and political development of film and television in Mexico and iterrogates the ways in which discourses of nationalism inform culture and media policy in relation to a local/global dialectic.

FAMST 128AAZZ.title: Topics in Film, Television, and Digital Comedy
FAMST 128AAZZ.description: Topics in this series examine various genres and forms of comedy produced for film, television, or other media, with attention to relevant sources, themes, performance styles, comic structures, creative figures, and social and historical contexts.

FAMST 134.title: French and Francophone Cinema
FAMST 134.description: Addresses the interaction between the institutions of French and francophone culture through cinema. The shifting terms of French identity in France and among French-speaking communities are examined through national, regional, and immigrant discourse. In English.

FAMST 140.title: The Western
FAMST 140.description: Establishes the forms and rituals of the western genre, and reflects on changes they have undergone. Attention will also be given to the trend toward realism, and the new moral and political revisions of the western's view of society.

FAMST 142.title: The War Film
FAMST 142.description: A study of films depicting and/or discussing warfare from World War I to Vietnam and beyond. Special emphasis on the relationship between the periods in which the films were made and the manner in which the wars were depicted.

FAMST 143.title: Science Fiction Film
FAMST 143.description: Examines the evolution and shifting limits of the genre from the dawn of narrative cinema through the heyday of the fifties' science fiction thriller through the recent high-tech revival in an age of media transformation.

FAMST 144.title: The Horror Film
FAMST 144.description: Study of the horror film genre and the reasons for its popularity, including new interest in psychoanalysis and reaction to modern mass society and consumerism. Covers issues of sacrifice, simulated catastrophicloss, and other themes of catharsis.

FAMST 147.title: The Thriller
FAMST 147.description: Study of the genre from the gangster to the science-fiction thriller, involving primarily American films but with a look at the parallel international cinema. Course centers on detection and investigation, exploring suspense and other intense forms of spectator involvement.

FAMST 148AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Film Aesthetics
FAMST 148AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit provided letter designations are different, but only 12 units may be applied toward the major.
FAMST 148AAZZ.description: Exploration in detail, of a single aspect of the film experience in relation to aesthetic and analytical issues. Topics may include the sound track, camera movement, mise-en-  scene, color, music, widescreen, acting, narrative, time, art design, editing.

FAMST 150AAZZ.title: Topics In Film Genre
FAMST 150AAZZ.comments: Course may be repeated an unlimited number of times, provided the letter designations are different but only 12 units may count toward the major.
FAMST 150AAZZ.description: A study in depth of one or two film genres, including historical, theoretical, and social issues. Topics will vary.

FAMST 151AAZZ.title: American Film History
FAMST 151AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units provided the letter designations are different, but only 8 units may be applied toward the major.
FAMST 151AAZZ.description: Examines major American film directors, genres, and themes within the context of the social concerns of a particular historical period.

FAMST 154PG.title: Topics in Film and Popular Culture
FAMST 154PG.prereq_description: FAMST 46 or 70 or junior status or consent of instructor.
FAMST 154PG.description: The course approaches pornography as a major instance of film and popular culture, from the pre-history and history of cinema and video to the Internet and virtual worlds. Course content augmented by guest lectures from the adult industry and academia.

FAMST 155AAZZ.title: Directors
FAMST 155AAZZ.comments: Course may be repeated an unlimited number of times, provided the letter designations are different. Only eight units may be counted for credit inthe major.
FAMST 155AAZZ.description: A study in depth of the films of one or two filmmakers of international stature and significance.

FAMST 163.title: Women and Film: Feminist Perspectives
FAMST 163.description: Survey of the major debates on questions of women and representation in contemporary film criticism. Topics to be covered include the representation of sexuality and the family in the Hollywood cinema; feminism and the avant-garde.

FAMST 165AAZZ.title: Film and Social Reality
FAMST 165AAZZ.prereq_description: Film Studies 46 or upper-division standing; consent of department.
FAMST 165AAZZ.description: An inquiry into the interrelationships between film and history and/or film and ideology. The course examines how cinema reflects and/or influences the attitudes of a society.

FAMST 166AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Cultural Studies
FAMST 166AAZZ.description: Uses cultural studies as a critical paradigm to closely examine a particular topic or theme.

FAMST 169.title: Film Noir
FAMST 169.description: Study of the conventional themes, structures, and visual motifs of the detective film. American films of the forties and fifties and contemporary American and European works will be considered.

FAMST 175.title: Experimental Film
FAMST 175.description: A survey of the experimental film tracing the major stylistic and thematic trends in the diverse movements that have considered themselves outside of the commercial narrative cinema. Bunuel, Dulac, Cocteau, Leger, Deren, Brakhage, Baillie, Frampton, Snow, Rainer, and others.

FAMST 182.title: Introduction to Environmental Media
FAMST 182.description: Ties the acquisition of critical viewing skills for film to the practice of conceiving and writing short environmental documentaries.  Students screen narrative films and documentaries, deconstruct them, and use their new proficiency to write their own documentary treatments.

FAMST 183.title: Film and Media of the Natural and Human Environment
FAMST 183.prereq_description: Film and Media Studies 46 or junior status.
FAMST 183.description: Presents popular films, professional documentaries representing  trends, images, and issues associated with natural and human environments. Visual images and critical thinking skills are combined to enhance understanding of media presentation of environmental issues. May be linked to short creative projects.

FAMST 184.title: Film Music
FAMST 184.description: Examines the musical score as an integral structural element of cinema. topics include the model of "silent" cinema; the theoretical basis of soundand image synchronicity; the narrative functions of film music; and contemporary development of the film score.

FAMST 187AAZZ.title: Topics in Film and Television Analysis
FAMST 187AAZZ.prereq_description: Film studies 46 or upper-division standing, and consent of instructor.
FAMST 187AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units provided letter designations are different, but only 8 units may be applied toward the major.
FAMST 187AAZZ.description: A seminar for advanced students examining in-depth a particular problem or issue in the analysis of film and its consequences for history, theory, or aesthetics of film, television and digital media.

FAMST 188A.title: Basic Screenwriting
FAMST 188A.prereq_description: Consent of instructor, writing sample, upper-division standing.
FAMST 188A.description: A study of the creativity and the technique of screenwriting for the conventional narrative film and for TV. Students will be required to complete writing exercises, a treatment, and master scenes of a full-lengthproject.

FAMST 188AD.title: Writing Adaptations
FAMST 188AD.comments:
Open to non-majors. Not open to students who have completed Film and Media Studies 113AD.
Repeat Comments: Not open to students who have completed Film and Media Studies 113AD.
FAMST 188AD.description: Theory and practice of adapting screenplays from other genres - novels, stories, plays, poems, video games, comics, articles, etc. Lectures and readings in the theory of adaptation. Screenplays written in short form and/or long form, narrative and/or post-modern.

FAMST 188AU.title: Autobiographical Screenwriting
FAMST 188AU.comments: Not open to students who have completed Film and Media Studies 113AU.
FAMST 188AU.description: An approach to the basics of screenwriting: structure, story, characters, with an emphasis on developing a writing project derived from personal experience. Students are required to complete writing exercises, a treatment, and master scenes of a full-length project.

FAMST 188B.title: Advanced Screenwriting
FAMST 188B.description: A course intended for students who have successfully completed Film Studies188A and have a full-length screenplay in process which they want to complete.

FAMST 188C.title: Writing Short Films
FAMST 188C.comments: Students are required to submit a writing sample.
FAMST 188C.description: An introduction to screenwriting, emphasizing the fundamentals of short film and T.V.: setup, climax and resolution, "character-driven" story and plot, the role of conflict, principles of action, exposition, and premise. Students are required to write two short films.

FAMST 188NM.title: Writing for New Media
FAMST 188NM.description: Students write scenarios for video games, iPod videos, short internet videos/films, flash fiction, flash poetry, blogs, et. al. Readings provide understanding of new media in their historical, theoretical, and political-social contexts.

FAMST 188SS.title: Storytelling for the Screen
FAMST 188SS.prereq_description: Consent of instructor, writing sample, upper-division standing.
FAMST 188SS.description: Part one of a two-part program. Aimed at students who already have basic screenwriting strengths, and are in the intermediate-to-advanced skill range. While focus will depend on the writer-in-residence, the course will include sessions in plot and structure, character and dialogue, tension and conflict, tone and symbolism, and revision strategies.

FAMST 188TV.title: Writing for Television
FAMST 188TV.comments: Students are required to submit a writing sample.
FAMST 188TV.description: Introduction to fundamentals of writing for television including: the situation comedy, the hour-long drama, the MOW, the miniseries, and children's programming. Investigation of the practical and creative tools necessary for programming. Investigation of the practical and creative tools necessary for navigating successful television scripts.

FAMST 188WS.title: Workshop for the Screen
FAMST 188WS.prereq_description: Consent of instructor, writing sample, upper-division standing.
FAMST 188WS.description: Part two of a two-part program. Team workshop structure will allow students to expand their screenwriting skills through a fundamental and intensive story-writing experience, an immersive and craft-focused writing calendar, with access to seasoned writers. Emphasis on multiple rounds of table-readings and group critiques.

FAMST 189AAZZ.title: Topics in Contemporary Media Theory
FAMST 189AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units provided letter designations are different, but only 8 units may be applied toward the major.
FAMST 189AAZZ.description: Topics vary each year and may include such problems as the relation of film and other media to structuralism, semiotics, metaphor/metonymy, point of view, and the writings of Burch, Barthes, Metz, Heath, Bordwell, Willemen, Wollen.

FAMST 190AAZZ.title: Studies in Film, Media and the Other Arts
FAMST 190AAZZ.prereq_description: Film Studies 46 or upper-division standing, and consent of instructor.
FAMST 190AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units provided the letter designations are different, but only 8 units may be applied toward the major.
FAMST 190AAZZ.description: An analysis of film and other media in relation to literary and plastic arts such as photography, architecture, and the novel. Topics vary.

FAMST 192AAZZ.title: Topics in Film and Media Theory
FAMST 192AAZZ.prereq_description: Film and Media 96 with a grade of C or better.
FAMST 192AAZZ.description: Addresses film, television and/or digital media from a variety of theoretical perspectives; topics will vary depending on instructor. Critical analytical papers will be required. Emphases have included classical, contemporary and comparative theories of film and media.

FAMST 195I.title: Internship in Film/Television
FAMST 195I.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; open to film studies majors only; consent of
FAMST 195I.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA for the preceding 3 quarters.
FAMST 195I.description: An opportunity for training, career sampling, and contacts in the film or television industry. Required are approximately 100 hours of work a quarter, a final five-page report, and a supervisor's letter of verification.

FAMST 195PI.title: Pollock Theater Event and Production Internship
FAMST 195PI.description: Students gain professional skills, including writing event proposals, marketing, and theater operations. Over three quarters, this class emphasizes different aspects of broadcast production, which include Q&As/talk shows, sitcoms, and directing. May be taken up to three times.

FAMST 196.title: Senior Honors Seminar
FAMST 196.description: A one-quarter directed study, to be conducted as outlined in the description of the Senior Honors Program. Honors candidates will write a senior thesis on a topic approved by film studies faculty.

FAMST 199.title: Independent Studies
FAMST 199.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in film
FAMST 199.comments: Students must have a 3.0 GPA for the preceding 3 quarters and are limitedto 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
FAMST 199.description: Selected research under the direction of a faculty member.

FAMST 199RA.title: Independent Research Assistance in Film Studies
FAMST 199RA.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in film studies; consent of instructor and department.
FAMST 199RA.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA for the preceding 3 quarters and arelimited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
FAMST 199RA.description: Course work shall consist of faculty supervised research assistance.

FAMST 210.title: Media Production
FAMST 210.prereq_description: Open to film and media studies majors only.
FAMST 210.description: Graduate-level instruction in film or video pre-production, production, and post-production.

FAMST 213.title: Autobiographical Screenwriting
FAMST 213.description: Explores the creative process in autobiographical screenplay construction through writing exercises as well as film viewing. Seeks innovative means of character and story development including but not limited to internet personas and autobiographical tourism.

FAMST 220.title: Critical Analysis and Method
FAMST 220.description: Seminar examining a range of methodologies and critical approaches to the study of film and media, with the specific topics chosen by the instructor.

FAMST 222AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Film Analysis
FAMST 222AAZZ.description: Close examination of an element of film style - such as sound, color, or camera movement - and its impact on interpretation.

FAMST 223.title: Black Film Criticism
FAMST 223.description: Explores the social, cultural, aesthetic, and economic contexts of black critical writing on film over the past century. Studies the black critique of racial representation in Hollywood and other cinemas, the black independent cinemas, and issues of black spectatorship.

FAMST 224.title: Genre Analysis
FAMST 224.description: Genre criticism illuminates the artistic and popular appeal of film and explores the relation of aesthetics to ideology. Course analyzes genre criticism through the lens of genre theory, reexamining conventional approaches to the nature and history of formulaic films.

FAMST 225.title: Film and Media Authorship
FAMST 225.description: Examines theories of authorship in film and television and how these ideas are redefined and questioned in a poststructuralist and postmodernist paradigm as well as with the evolution of interactive technologies.

FAMST 226.title: National Cinemas
FAMST 226.description: Close analysis of theories of nation, nationalism, and national  cinema, with a focus on the contentious relations between culture,  history, media capital and the state. Topics include evolving genres,  styles, movements and institutions; local lifeworlds and cultural  difference within a post-national context; and the spectral nature of  contemporary national formations.  Offered concurrently with Film Studies 187AA-ZZ.

FAMST 230.title: Philosophy of Film History
FAMST 230.description: Studies works and concepts in the philosophy of history that have informed the researching and writing of film and media history. Will also consider the ways in which film and media texts have extended debates and concepts of historiographic practice.

FAMST 231.title: Media Historiographies
FAMST 231.description: Comparative analysis of various historical accounts of cinema, television, and digital media that have shaped the field of film and media studies. Emphasis on issues and debates that have dominated efforts to write rigorous, methodologically explicit histories of different media.

FAMST 232AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Film and Media History
FAMST 232AAZZ.description: Close examination of a topic in film and/or media history.

FAMST 233.title: Histories of Film Style
FAMST 233.description: Examines different explanatory models for patterns of historical continuity, influence, and change in film style. Also includes comparative study of influential models for the history of style in other art forms, such as painting, photography, architecture, music, and literature.

FAMST 234.title: History, Memory, and Media
FAMST 234.description: Explores how visual and acoustic media have influenced the writing of public histories and the formation of collective memories, and the possibilities and limitations of representing historical events in both fiction and non-fiction audio-visual forms.

FAMST 235.description: Studies modes of documentary filmmaking in the context of literary and cinematic self-representation including the relationships among personal and collective history and identity construction.

FAMST 236.title: Historicizing New Media
FAMST 236.description: Looks at issues of media production and consumption along an historical continuum including changing patterns of media literacy, types of apparatuses, ideologies, ethics, and aesthetics.

FAMST 240.title: Film Theory
FAMST 240.description: Examines the history and rhetoric of thinking about the ontology, epistemology, ideology, and aesthetics of film.

FAMST 241.title: Television and Digital Media Theory
FAMST 241.description: Explores important theoretical writings concerning electronic and digital media. Course readings define the unique properties of these mediums, consider their ontological status, and discuss how they differ from one another and other cultural forms.

FAMST 242AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Film and Media Theory
FAMST 242AAZZ.description: Close examination of a topic in film and/or media theory.

FAMST 243AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Critical Thinkers
FAMST 243AAZZ.description: Explores in depth the work of one particular thinker relevant to the field of media and cultural studies, for example, Freud, Barthes, Benjamin, and others.

FAMST 244.title: Rhetoric of Film Theories
FAMST 244.description: Examines the forms of language and conventions of reasoning that sustain major film theories.

FAMST 245.title: Narrative Theory and Memory
FAMST 245.description: Theories of narrative and their relationship to the human mind, traumatic experience, and the evocation of emotion.

FAMST 247.title: Feminism and Media Theory
FAMST 247.description: An intellectual history of feminist film and television theory from the 1970s to the present. Course readings are discussed in relation to gender representations in various screenings. Areas covered include psychoanalysis, structuralism, poststructuralism, queer theory, and cultural studies.

FAMST 248.title: Digital Media Theory and Practices
FAMST 248.description: Studies the emerging theoretical paradigms and creative practices of new media technologies including the Internet, computer games, CD-ROM, DVD, and wireless communication devices. Also examines how technologies mediate, perpetuate, and challenge social, cultural, political, and economic institutions and humanistic values.

FAMST 249.title: Postcolonial Media Theory
FAMST 249.description: Studies colonial ideologies and representations, and postcolonial challenges and negotiations, with an emphasis on concepts such as imperialism, Eurocentricism, Orientalism, Third Cinema, hybridity, voice, and identity. Interrogates the institutions, frameworks, and processes involved in the production of knowledge.

FAMST 250.title: Cultural Theory
FAMST 250.description: Explores key ideas, issues, and developments in cultural studies and critical theory through close readings of primary texts.  Possible approaches include the Frankfurt School, the Birmingham School, Freudianism/Lacanianism, semiotics/structuralism, and postmodernism/post-structuralism.

FAMST 251.title: Popular Culture
FAMST 251.description: Surveys contemporary approaches to the study of popular culture. Readings include theorists who have critically engaged the Frankfurt School, who have written before and beyond the Birmingham School, or who have taken a comparative international perspective.

FAMST 252AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Cultural Studies
FAMST 252AAZZ.description: Close examination of a topic in cultural studies.

FAMST 254.title: The Inhuman and Posthuman in Digital Culture
FAMST 254.description: Examines the rhetorics and aesthetics of digital media technologies, especially as they construct new epistemologies and ontologies of representing/mediating the human condition, paying particular attention to claims that new digital technologies have transformed the liberal Enlightenment subject into the posthuman.

FAMST 255.title: Gaming Culture
FAMST 255.description: The computer games industry rivals film and television for audience discretionary income. This course focuses on computer game theories, genres, aesthetics, industrial histories and practices, and representational discourses.

FAMST 260.title: Film and Ethnography
FAMST 260.description: Brings the techniques of film analysis to bear on the films, videos, and writings of leading visual anthropologists, such as Tim Asch, Jorge Preloran, and Dennis O'Rourke.

FAMST 262AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Film and/or Media Globalization
FAMST 262AAZZ.description: Close examination of a topic in globalization of film and/or media.

FAMST 263.title: Cultural Translation
FAMST 263.description: Defines and examines the problematic of "transition" as the circulation of cultural texts beyond borders and boundaries (temporal, linguistic, institutional, communal, national, regional, and disciplinary).

FAMST 266.title: Political Economy of Global Media
FAMST 266.description: Examines media institutions and networks of exchange, focusing on their transformation, shifting power relations, and emerging geopolitical imaginations.

FAMST 267.title: Media Industries
FAMST 267.description: The business strategies, political economy, regulatory dimensions and cultural products of contemporary media industries. A focus on the dynamics of globalization, convergence and new technologies grounds our exploration of the interconnected industrial, economic and cultural/artistic aspects of film, television, and digital media.

FAMST 268.title: Paradigms of Globalization
FAMST 268.description: Analysis of various theories of globalization, with specific focus on 'global media.' Interrogates the ways in which transnational networks and flows of capital, information, technology, people, representations, aspirations and actions are constitutive of contemporary life.

FAMST 295I.title: Professional Internship
FAMST 295I.prereq_description: Consent of department; film studies majors only; must be in good standing.
FAMST 295I.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA.
FAMST 295I.description: An opportunity for training, career sampling, and contacts in the media industry.

FAMST 501.title: Teaching Assistant Practicum
FAMST 501.description: Designed to accommodate graduate students who serve as teaching assistants. Includes analyses of texts and materials, discussion section teaching techniques, formulation of topics and questions for papers and examinations, and grading papers and examinations under instructor supervision.

FAMST 593.title: Programming and Curation Practicum
FAMST 593.comments:
Open to non-majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Fall. Graduate students from any department are eligible to enroll in 1 or 2 units. For electivecredit toward the Film and Media Studies PhD, students must register for 2 units in each of the two terms.
Repeat Comments: FAMST PhD students taking the course for 2 units are limited to 2 quarters total. Anyone enrolled for 1 unit may repeat for a total of 4 units.
FAMST 593.description: Examines issues related to curation, including the construction of canons, cultural value, and economies of prestige. Students work with the CWC director in curating programs for the Pollock Theater and related research events. Class discusses readings, screen media, research potential guests, writes questions for Q&A sessions with invited guests, and writes program notes for the CWC's website and Pollock programs. Students register for one unit per quarter. If taken for elective credit toward the Film and Media Studies PhD, it must be taken for two terms in a row, two units in each of the two terms.

FAMST 594AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Film and Media
FAMST 594AAZZ.description: A seminar on research subjects of current interest.

FAMST 595AAZZ.title: Group Studies
FAMST 595AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit provided letter designations are different. Nocredit allowed toward advanced degrees.
FAMST 595AAZZ.description: Provides guidance, training, a forum, and a common center for various research endeavors.

FAMST 597.title: MA Orals and PhD Exam Preparation
FAMST 597.comments: No unit credit allowed toward advanced degree.
FAMST 597.description: Master's Oral Exam and PhD Qualifying Exam preparation.

FAMST 598.title: Preparation for Dissertation Prospectus
FAMST 598.prereq_description: To be taken prior to the qualifying exam.
FAMST 598.description: Preparation for the Ph.D. qualifying exam and writing of the dissertation prospectus.

FAMST 599.title: Dissertation Research and Writing
FAMST 599.description: Only for the research and writing of dissertation. Instructor should be chair of the student's doctoral committee.
